Despite  many  initiatives  aimed  at  developing  Balochistan’s  economic 
and  social  sectors,  the  development  remains  below  its  potential,  and 
social  indicators  lag  those  of  other  provinces.  Incidence  of  poverty 
remains very high. Fiscal space available to the Balochistan provincial 
government (BPG) is extremely limited. Expenditures allocated do not 
adequately  reflect  medium-term  policy  priorities.  Transparency  and 
accountability  mechanisms  need  to  be  improved;  access  to  justice 
remains  inadequate.  Allocations  are  inadequate  to  cover  the  growing 
needs  for  operation  and  maintenance  of  public  services.  Water 
resources are severely degraded and form a limiting factor to growth. 
In  sum,  a  lack  of  good  governance  has  been  identified  as  a  central 
element responsible for continuing low growth  and increasing poverty 
within Balochistan.

The realization of program benefits and impacts will depend on several 
assumptions that are subject to a variety of risks. Mitigating measures

Political  Risks.  The  political  situation  in  Balochistan  tends  to  be 
difficult.  The  coalition  government  has  a  wide  constituency  to  satisfy 
and therefore faces pressures. Secondly, some conflicts have arisen in 
building  political  consensus  around  large-scale  development  projects 
initiated by the federal Government. In addition, Balochistan’s borders 
with  neighboring  countries  are  porous,  smuggling  is  rampant  and 
enforcement  of  law  suffers  by  having  separate  and  coexisting  rules 
and  enforcement  systems  in  some  parts  of  the  province.  These  risks 
are  exacerbated  by  the  size  and  rugged  terrain  of  the  province,  and 
the  sparse  and  dispersed  population,  which  makes  administrative 
reach more difficult. 
 
The  BRMP  will  not  be  able  to  mitigate  all  these  risks.  Some, 
particularly  those  related  to  the  geopolitical  aspects,  are  beyond  the 
control  of  Balochistan  and  even  the  federal  Government.  The  BRMP 
will  assist  BPG  to  develop  its  governance  infrastructure  to  mitigate 
some  of  these  risks.  An  essential  part  of  the  BRMP  is  continuous 
dialogue  with  stakeholders.  The  BRMP  includes  a  communication 
strategy  that  began  with  water  resources  management  issues  (in 
particular  on  agricultural  tubewell  reform)  under  the  preparatory  TA. 
The  strategy  will  be  extended  to  all  reform  areas  of  the  BRMP  to 
ensure  continuity  of  support  through  all  stakeholders.  The  BRMP 
achieved  strong  political  backing  through  the  budget  speech  and  the 
white paper for FY2005 to overcome practices of approving unrealistic 
development  schemes.  Managing  public  resources  in  an  efficient, 
transparent,  accountable,  and  sustainable  manner  is  an  important

2. 
Economic  Assessment  and  Outlook.  Pakistan’s  economic  performance  continues  to 
improve, and key macroeconomic fundamentals during fiscal year (FY) 2004 were better than at 
any time in the past decade. In FY2004, the gross domestic product (GDP) increased by 6.4% 
compared with 5.1% in FY2003. The manufacturing sector, a major contributor, grew by 13.1% 
in FY2004, followed by the services sector with 5.2%. However, the agriculture sector grew by 
only  2.6%.  The  fiscal  deficit  was  dropped  to  3.9%  of  GDP  in  FY2004  from  4.5%  in  FY2003. 
Growth in exports was robust (increasing by 10% to $12.3 billion) and the level of remittances 
high.  Imports  expanded  rapidly  (by  26.6%,  reaching  $15.5  billion),  and  the  current  account 
surplus  was  reduced  to  $1,369  million  in  the  first  9  months  of  FY2004,  compared with  $2,706 
million  during  the  same  period  in  FY2003.  For  the  fourth  consecutive  year  Pakistan  had  a 
balance of payments surplus and, as a result, foreign exchange reserves held by the State Bank 
of  Pakistan  (SBP)  increased  to  $10.6  billion  in  June  2004,  equivalent  to  over  8  months  of 
imports.  
 
3. 
Growth,  Investment,  and  Savings.  In  FY2004,  value-added  in  the  manufacturing 
sector  increased  by  13.4%,  and  in  large-scale  manufacturing  by  17.1%,  the  highest  growth 
achieved  in  the  last  2  decades.  With  excess  capacity  available  in  most  industries  at  the 
beginning  of  the  year,  manufacturing  production  increased.  Domestic  demand  surged,  fuelled 
by an unprecedented increase in consumer credit, higher cash incomes of cotton farmers, and 
continuing high level of remittances. Investment increased with gross fixed capital formation in 
constant  prices  rising  by  14.7%  compared  with  a  1.0%  increase  in  FY2003.  Inclusive  of 
accumulation of stocks, total investment increased from 16.7% of GDP to 18.1%. Foreign direct 
investment increased significantly in FY2004 (for the third consecutive year). During the first 11 
months, foreign direct investment totaled $903 million, 21.2% higher than in the corresponding 
period of FY2003. Gross domestic savings remained unchanged at 17.4% of GDP in FY2004.  
 
4.

Impact of Decentralization. Local governments now have primary responsibility for the 
bulk  of  service  delivery  (including  elementary  education,  curative  health,  rural  development, 
farm  to  market  roads  and  municipal  services).  Provincial  governments  are  expected  to  evolve 
so  that  their  departments  (including  communications  and  works,  education,  health,  and  local 
government  and  rural  development)  are  reoriented  to  provide  policy  advice  to  local 
governments,  review  their  performance  in  key  areas,  and  provide  technical  and  mentoring 
support  to  local  governments  and  service  provision  agencies.  To  carry  out  these  functions 
effectively,  provincial  governments  must  ensure  that  fiscal  and  financial  management  is 
improved  significantly;  adequate  resources  are  available  for  development  spending;  and  that 
intergovernmental  financing  systems  function  effectively.10  In  addition,  provincial  governments 
continue to be responsible for policy implementation in key sectors such as irrigation and water 
management, as well as industries and private sector development.

21.  Water  Resources  Management.  Balochistan  has  scarce  water  resources.  The 
environment has been severely degraded in recent years, due to a combination of factors, the 
most  important  of  which  is  the  drought,  which  prevailed  for  most  of  the  last  5  years. 
Groundwater resources have been severely depleted, rangelands degraded, forests decimated, 
and agricultural land rendered uncultivable, with a strong negative impact on levels of increased 
rural  poverty.  The  rate  of  exploitation  of  the  natural  resource  base  is  unsustainable,  and  the 
continued  degradation  of  the  environment  is  likely  to  result  in  increases  in  poverty,  given  the 
inextricable linkage of environment-development issues in the province. Water basin resources 
vary  widely,  with  some  basins  having  one  half  to  one  third  of  the  average  water  resources. 
Inefficient water use, wastage of surface water, and indiscriminate exploitation of groundwater 
coupled with water scarcity have aggravated the scarcity, making water management a complex 
and difficult task. Presently, only 30% of the available water is utilized. A severe problem relates 
to the growing rate of agricultural tubewells, which are adding to degradation of the water table, 
and to the province’s subsidy burden. The subsidy for electricity used by agricultural tubewells is 
open-ended, with no incentive for farmers to conserve energy or save scarce water resources.

35. 
A  central  element  of  BPG’s  poor  development  performance  entails  significant 
governance issues encompassing public institutions and functions at all levels. Improvements in 
public  sector  governance  and  resource  management  are  known  to  yield  considerable 
development  gains.  For  Balochistan,  the  key  governance  challenge  lies  in  ensuring  effective 
functioning of decentralized systems of governance. Strengthening public policy formulation and 
fostering  participatory,  transparent,  and  accountable  systems  and  processes  are  other 
elements. Economic activity is unlikely to accelerate unless conditions improve significantly, and 
access to justice is ensured to all sections of society. 
 
36. 
Issues of Devolution. Since Pakistan initiated its ambitious Devolution Plan in 2001, a 
major  transition  process  has  been  ongoing.  All  tiers  of  government  need  to  comply  with  their 
new  roles  and  responsibilities.  Systems  and  processes still  have  to  be  fully  institutionalized  to 
achieve the awaited higher benefits of better public service delivery. So far, the process has not 
been backed-up by the transfer of political, administrative, and fiscal decision-making authority 
and  resources.  This  is  leading  to  unrealistic  popular  expectations  and  frustration  over  the 
perceived  lack  of  concrete  visible  products,  despite  some  improvements  in  public  service 
delivery.  The  legacy  of  multiple  side-by-side  agencies  with  uneven  roles,  responsibilities,  and 
resources remains. The dual structure has been maintained in districts and municipalities with 
the existence of both provincial departments and local governments with limited resources. 
 
37. 
Local governments have not yet set up linkages across jurisdictions as stipulated in the 
Balochistan Local  Government  Ordinance  (BLGO).  The  local  government  commission  has  not 
been  constituted  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the  law  and  has  yet  to  be  made  fully 
functional. Zila musharwat (district consultation) committees have not assumed an effective role 
(and  in  some  cases,  have  not  been  constituted)  and  joint  committees  of  district  governments 
and of tehsil18 municipal administrations (TMAs) have not been formed. 
 
38. 
Lack of Administrative Decentralization. While responsibility for providing basic public 
services  in  health,  education,  water,  and  sanitation  have  clearly  been  assigned  to  local 
governments under the law, commensurate administrative authority and staff have not yet been 
assigned. Public health engineering staff have been retained at the district rather than devolved 
to  TMAs.  Works  department  staff  have  been  transferred,  while  repair  and  maintenance  funds 
and  all  development  expenditure  are  retained  by  the  provincial  department.  BPG  controls 
personnel  management  and  continues  to  exercise  administrative  powers  over  postings  and 
transfers.  BPG  staff  working  for  district  governments  retain  direct  links  with  their  provincial 
administrative departments at the cost of horizontal linkages and coordination within the district 
government.  Areas  such  as  recruitment  and  intergovernment  relations  in  terms  of  monitoring 
responsibilities  are  still  fairly  fluid.  This  situation  seriously  hampers  the  ability  of  local 
governments to enforce discipline and hold staff accountable for performance, let alone embark 
on  rationalization,  restructuring,  and  redeployment.  The  responsibilities  assigned  to  the  local 
governments under the local government legislation cannot be exercised in the absence of rules 
framed  by  BPG.  These  include  rules  transferring  powers  for  appointment,  postings  and 
transfers;  administrative  approval  and  technical  sanction  of  development  schemes;  and 
enforcement of efficiency and discipline rules.

45. 
Increasing Demand for Water. As human and livestock populations increase, demand 
for water is increasing. The annual growth rate of tubewell-irrigated areas is alarming, indicating 
growing demand for  water in the  agriculture sector. The future increase in demand for human 
and  livestock  populations  will  largely  be  met  from  the  existing  share  of  the  agriculture  sector, 
thus groundwater available for agriculture will continue to decrease. The problem is exacerbated 
by  reduced  stream  flows  during  droughts,  which  impact  wetlands  and  marshes  in  low-lying 
areas.  Ensuring  minimum  water  requirement  for  nature  and  ecosystem  needs  will  affect  the 
availability of surface water. 
 
46. 
Excessive Mining of Groundwater. The dramatic increase in the number of tubewells 
followed the introduction of the national electricity grid system in the 1970s. The annual growth 
rate of electric tubewells during the last 17 years is around 6.7% and of diesel tubewells around 
7.4%. The increasing use of tubewells has resulted in lowering of the water table and mining of 
groundwater.  In  spite  of  this,  additional  tubewells  are  being  installed  to  meet  the  rural,  urban, 
and  agriculture  requirements.  The  reasons  for  unsustainable  groundwater  mining  include  (i) 
continued  increase  in  water  demand,  (ii)  lack  of  incentives  for  efficient  water  use  due  to  the 
heavily  subsidized  electricity  tariff,  (iii)  unsustainable  level  of  groundwater  abstraction,  (iv) 
neglect  of  natural  recharge  systems,  and  (v)  ineffective  and  costly  techniques  for  inducing 
recharge to the groundwater. Almost all fruits, vegetables, and winter fodders are over irrigated. 
Trickle irrigation schemes are being tried, but are not widely accepted by farmers as water is not 
a  priced  commodity.  The  provincial  concept  of  farm  water  management  was  adopted  from 
canal-irrigated areas and has not been adapted to the fragile ecosystems of the province.

4.  

Lessons Learned 

Lessons can be drawn from previous experience in policy-based adjustment lending by 
50. 
ADB and other funding agencies in Pakistan,19 as well as from ADB support for governance and 
resource  management  programs  elsewhere.  Considerable  experience  has  been  gained  with 
program  lending  in  Pakistan.  Since  1999,  ADB  has  approved  eight  program  or  sector 
development  program  loans.  Generally,  implementation  of  these  loans  has  been  progressing 
satisfactorily.  Key  lessons  learned  include  the  importance  of  ownership  and  a  committed 
executing  agency  to  drive  implementation;  need  for  broad-based  political  support  and 
consultation in particular for cross-sector reforms; focused design and realistic implementation 
time  frames;  and  strong  implementation  support,  including TA  loans.  A  stronger  focus  of  ADB 
on implementation is important to overcome delays in implementation.  
 
51. 
Familiarity  with  adjustment  lending  at  the  provincial  level  is  growing  in  Pakistan. 
Provincial  resource  management  programs  are  supported  in  Sindh  and  North-West  Frontier 
Province by World Bank, and in Punjab by ADB. Key lessons include the importance of taking 
into  account  provincial  considerations  and  capacities.  For  programs  of  such  complex  nature 
high-level  government  support  in  steering  committees  is  important  to  avoid  interdepartmental 
conflicts,  which  often  decelerate  implementation  progress.  Resource  management  programs 
should  always  be  designed  vehicles  to  sustain  continuous  policy  dialogue.  Therefore, 
consultation  is  not  only  important  in  the  program  design  phase  but  throughout  program 
implementation. To support dialogue, a communication strategy is essential to meet the different 
and  specific  stakeholder  needs.  Time  frames  should  not  be  too  short,  and  designs  should 
always support flexibility and sequencing of policy reform. These lessons are incorporated in the 
design and implementation arrangements of the BRMP.

Reducing  Poverty.  The  overarching  goal  of  the  BRMP  is  to  support  BPG’s  pro-poor 
53.

BRMP’s  purpose  is  to  enable  BPG  to  create  sustainable  fiscal  space  to  finance  the  cost  of 
structural adjustment, and to finance high-priority social and human development programs by 
local  governments  targeted  at  the  poor,  while  supporting  increased  participation  of  key 
stakeholders for transparent, accountable, and sustainable public service provision. Reforms of 
underlying systems and processes to manage public resources are important for reversing the 
increasing  incidence  of  poverty.  Therefore,  the  BRMP  supports  implementation  of  the 
Balochistan PRS (footnote 3) and strengthening of public policy formulation. 
 
54. 
The  federal  PRS  bases  poverty  reduction  on  the  four  pillars  of  (i)  increased  economic 
growth through sound macroeconomic management, fiscal and financial reforms, expansion of 
infrastructure, and rural development; (ii) improved governance and devolution; (iii) investment 
in  human  capital;  and  (iv)  targeting  of  the  poor  and  vulnerable.  In  addition  to  these,  the 
Balochistan  PRS  stresses  two  major  areas  of  specific  concern:  (i)  managing  scarce  water 
resources,  and  (ii)  addressing  vulnerability  to  shocks.  It  focuses  on  a  growth  strategy  that  is 
inclusive  of  the  poor  by  providing  improved  access  to  basic  education,  primary  health  care, 
adequate nutrition, safe water, and sanitation. Based on these focal areas and recognizing that 
most  of  these  public  service  delivery  functions  are  devolved,  the  BRMP  will  support 
mechanisms that improve the availability of financing for local governments.  
 
55. 
Realign Governance Structures, Systems, and Procedures. The purpose and policy 
objectives  of  the  BRMP  are  to  help  Balochistan  reform  governance  structures,  systems,  and 
procedures to 
 

(i)   provide fiscal space for sustainable and pro-poor development, and improve allocation 
and monitoring mechanisms for effective and transparent utilization of funds; and  
(ii)  create the enabling environment and supporting institutions for effective public service 

delivery, sustainable water management, and private sector development.  

 
56. 
Program  Modality.  Balochistan  needs  to  embark—like  the  other  provinces—on  wider 
and  holistic  reforms  to  make  its  policies  sustainable  and  reduce  its  dependence  on  federal 
Government transfers. Such reforms need to be sequenced over a long period. The BRMP by 
itself  can  only  trigger  the  reform  by  linking  multiple  commitments  under  one  umbrella.  The 
BRMP  intends  to  set  the  policy  path  for  other  ADB  investments,  such  as  the  proposed 
Balochistan  Rural  Development  and  Drought  Mitigation  Project  and  Balochistan  Devolved 
Social  Services  Program.  Secondly,  the  BRMP  aims  to  strengthen  ongoing  reforms,  most 
notably  the  Decentralization  Support  Program  (DSP)  and  the  Access  to  Justice  Program.  The 
BRMP is designed as a two tranche program covering 2 fiscal years. However, the BRMP will 
develop criteria that can lead to a second program. To support institutional development as well

supplemented by a substantial TA grant from the Government of the Netherlands. An advisory 
TA grant will augment the capacity for implementation and sustainability of the reform agenda 
under the BRMP. This TA will support capacity development for program implementation.

VI. 

PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACTS, AND RISKS 

A. 

Benefits 

111.  The BRMP outcomes will help BPG with its efforts to reduce poverty by embarking on a 
first set of broader policy reforms. Of utmost importance is the beginning of continuous dialogue 
between  BPG  and  ADB  on  holistic  policy  reforms.  A  prime  benefit  will  be  the  improvement  of 
public  policy  formulation  by  engaging  all  key  stakeholders.  Another  important  benefit  is  the 
development  of  the  BRMP’s  monitoring  and  evaluation  system,  which  will  not  only  allow  better 
poverty  targeted  monitoring  but  also  the  evaluation  of  outputs  and  outcomes  for  the  benefit  of 
future  policy  reforms.  Policy  reforms  will  enable  improved  public  service  delivery  by  creating 
fiscal  resources  that  allow  reprioritization  of  provincial  expenditures  and  reforms  in  revenue 
generation  and  expenditure  management.  Improvements  in  efficiency,  effectiveness,  and 
performance accountability of public sector agencies will reduce wastage and enable processes 
for sustainable management of public resources. By streamlining public resource management, 
the BRMP will create the fundamentals for more opportunities for private-sector-led growth and 
employment generation.  
 
112. 
Identifiable benefits will accrue over the medium term in line with the outcomes detailed in 
the  program  framework  and  policy  matrix.  Specific  and  immediate  impacts  will  relate  to  fiscal 
restructuring and utilization of loan proceeds for debt restructuring, which will create savings of as 
much  as  PRs1  billion  per  annum  on  debt  servicing.  This  will  be  utilized  for  improved  pro-poor 
service delivery in line with the agreed medium-term fiscal framework. In addition, several specific

actions directly targeting the poor are included in the policy matrix, such as creation of sustainable 
water  resources  management,  a  pro-poor  food  subsidy  policy,  and  improved  public  services 
targeted at the poor.  
 
B. 

Impacts 

113.  The  BRMP  is  expected  to  have  a  positive  impact  on  poverty  reduction  by  facilitating 
institutional  processes.  Impacts  on  labor  markets,  prices,  net  public  transfers,  and  access  to 
public goods and services are expected to be positive in the long term. No significant adverse 
impacts  are  directly  associated  with  the  BRMP.  The  BRMP  will  have  a  positive  impact  on 
gender  by  making  BRG  approval  of  the  GRAP  a  precondition  for  the  loans.  The  BRMP  will 
support GRAP implementation. A summary poverty reduction and social strategy is in Appendix 
9. A summary description on the poverty impact of the BRMP is in Supplementary Appendix H. 
Integration of gender reforms under the BRMP is in Appendix 10. 
 
114.  The  BRMP  will  have  positive  impacts  on  the  environment  by  developing  a  strategy 
leading  to  sustainable  water  resources  management,  and  developing  a  new  tubewell  policy. 
Measures  will  be  introduced  to  cap  and  phase  out  the  tubewell  subsidy  by  introducing  an 
incentive  system  that  encourages  sustainable  water  usage.  The  BRMP  will  not  have  any 
involuntary resettlement components or any impact on indigenous people. 
 
C. 

Risks 

115.  The  realization  of  program  benefits  and  impacts  will  depend  on  a  number  of 
assumptions that are subject to a variety of risks. Mitigating measures have been integrated in 
the  BRMP  design  as  appropriate,  taking  account  of  past  experiences  in  program  lending  in 
Pakistan and elsewhere. 
 
116.  Political  Risks.  The  political  situation  in  Balochistan  tends  to  be  difficult.  The  coalition 
government has a wide constituency to satisfy and therefore faces pressures. Secondly, some 
conflicts  have  arisen  in  building  political  consensus  around  large-scale  development  projects 
initiated  by  the  federal  Government.  In  addition,  Balochistan’s  borders  with  neighboring 
countries are porous, smuggling is rampant and enforcement of law suffers by having separate 
and  coexisting  rules  and  enforcement  systems  in  some  parts  of  the  province.  These  risks  are 
exacerbated  by  the  size  and  rugged  terrain  of  the  province,  and  the  sparse  and  dispersed 
population, which makes administrative reach more difficult. 
 
117.  The  BRMP  will  not  be  able  to  mitigate  all  these  risks.  Some  of  the  risks,  particularly 
those  related  to  the  geopolitical  aspects,  are  beyond  the  control  of  Balochistan  and  even  the 
federal Government. The BRMP will help BPG develop its governance infrastructure to mitigate 
some  of  these  risks.  An  essential  part  of  the  BRMP  is  continuous  dialogue  with  stakeholders. 
The BRMP includes a communication strategy, which began with water resources management 
issues (in particular on the tubewell reform) under the preparatory TA, and will be extended to 
all other reform areas of the BRMP to ensure continuity of support through all stakeholders. The 
BRMP  achieved  strong  political  backing  through  the  budget  speech  and  the  white  paper  for 
FY2005 to overcome practices of approving unrealistic development schemes. Managing public 
resources  in  an  efficient,  transparent,  accountable,  and  sustainable  manner  is  an  important 
precondition to control political risks. 
 
118.  Governance and Bureaucratic Risks. There is a risk that some people will be resistant 
to the new transparent and accountable processes and will be reluctant to change systems. To 

 26

 

 

mitigate  such  risks,  high-level  support  from  the  chief  secretary  and  the  high-level  steering 
committee  will  be  important.  Further  mitigation  of  risks  is  expected  by  undertaking  special 
audits, making accounts and expenditures publicly available, and establishing public grievance 
mechanisms under the BRMP. 
 
119. 
Institutional  and  Implementation  Risks.  Several  programs  and  projects  in  Pakistan 
suffer from implementation delays. Taking this into account, the BRMP builds on experiences of 
a  functioning  PMU  by  merging  program  implementation  with  the  DSP’s  Provincial  Program 
Support Office in Quetta. A detailed program administration memorandum will also assure the 
BRMP’s  focus  not  only  on  design  but  on  detailed  implementation.  To  further  mitigate  this  risk 
the BRMP  will have a  strong TA component focusing on capacity building to support program 
implementation, and thereby build institutional capacity.  
 
120.  Continuity  Risk.  Balochistan  has  a  very  high  overdraft  with  SBP.  Continuing  this 
practice  without  a  clear-cut  exit  strategy  will  set  disincentives  for  BPG  to  embark  on  holistic 
fiscal and financial management reforms. The BRMP incorporates the immediate freezing and 
reduction over time of the overdraft as part of overall fiscal consolidation. 
 
121.  Macroeconomic Risks. Pakistan’s macroeconomic parameters have been strong in the 
past 2 years. The initial broad policy reforms by the Government are beginning to show positive 
signs. However, poverty levels remain too high and changes in that regard are indispensable. 
 
122.  The  country  remains  highly  vulnerable  to  exogenous  shocks.  To  mitigate  such  risks  to 
the  extent  possible,  the  federal  Government  has  put  in  place  a  consistent  economic 
management strategy that aims to reduce debt and help ensure fiscal stabilization.

A. 
 
Balochistan  is  Pakistan's  largest  province  by  area,  covering  a  total  of  347,000 square 
1.

5% of the country’s total population) as per the 1998 census. This dichotomy has a number of 
implications for the socioeconomic conditions in the province. With a population density of only 
19 persons per square kilometer, and a predominantly rural population (76.1% of the total), the 
province is characterized by the presence of small, scattered settlements, many of which are 
not easily accessible. Estimates of incidence of poverty in the province are not very reliable due 
to data collection difficulties, but the Balochistan provincial government (BPG) estimated that in 
1999, at the height of the drought, 47% of the population was living below the poverty line.1 
 
2. 
The  bulk  of  Balochistan’s  labor  force  (65%)  is  employed  in  agriculture,  including  crop 
agriculture,  livestock,  and  fisheries.  Livestock  farming  is  the  predominant  activity  within  the 
sector,2 but following the 5-year drought that ended in 2002, only about a third of the total land 
area can be considered productive grazing land. The cultivated area is 2.11 million hectares (or 
10%  of  the  total  cultivated  area  in  the  country),  and  only  0.84  million  hectares  of  land  are 
irrigated.  More  than  a  third  of  the  cultivated  area  is  concentrated  in  four  districts,  which  have 
irrigation  systems.  Although  major  crops  such  as  wheat,  rice,  and  cotton  are  grown,  it  is  in 
horticulture  that  the  province  has  a  comparative  advantage,  with  fruit  production  estimated at 
about 1.4 million tons annually. The province has a 770 km coastline, and the fisheries sector 
constitutes an important subsector of agriculture, with production valued at about PRs1.4 billion 
annually. 
 
3. 
The province has a very limited industrial base, with the manufacturing sector employing 
only  3.4%  of  the  population.  Almost  all  industrial  activity  is  concentrated  in  the  district  of 
Lasbela, which borders Karachi. The district houses four industrial estates, while Quetta district 
has two more. Occupancy levels in the industrial estates are extremely low (less than 5% in all 
cases).  The  potential  for  mining  in  Balochistan  is  considerable,  given  that  39  minerals  are 
currently  being  mined  in  the  province,  and  commercial  deposits  of  an  additional  11  are 
estimated.3 Balochistan also supplies 70% of the country’s estimated production of natural gas, 
the bulk of it from the Sui gas fields. Overall, the province has been unable to attract investment 
because  of  lack  of  infrastructure,  unavailability  of  skilled  labor,  and  prevalence  of  a  social 
system that encourages rent-seeking behavior on the part of local elites.  
 
4. 
Balochistan’s  natural  environment  is  harsh,  with  an  arid  climate,  scarcity  of  water 
resources,  and  a  rugged  terrain  for  the  most  part.  These  factors  have  contributed  to  the  low 
population density, and may also have played a part in the development of the entrenched tribal 
system  that  characterizes  the  sociocultural  environment.  The  scattered  population,  heavily 
dependent  on  the  patronage  of  local  elites,  has  little  access  to  social  services,  which  are,  in 
these  circumstances,  expensive  to  provide  and  maintain.  As  a  result,  Balochistan’s  social 
indicators consistently rank near the bottom in Pakistan, falling well below  national averages in 
most  cases.  In  rural  Balochistan,  the  literacy  rate  is  estimated  at  14%  as  compared  with  the

6. 
Constitutional Provisions.  The  allocation  of  responsibilities  between  the  federal  and 
provincial governments is specified in the Fourth Schedule (under Article 4) of the Constitution 
of Pakistan of 1973. The Federal Legislative List sets out the functions to be performed by the 
federal  Government,  while  the  Concurrent  List  delineates  the  functions  that  can  be  performed 
either by the federal or the provincial governments; although in the event of any conflict between 
the legislation of the two tiers of government that of the federal Government prevails. Residual 
functions, not enumerated in either list, are the responsibility of the provinces.  
 
7. 
Federal Government Functions. According to the Federal Legislative List, the federal 
Government is responsible for regulatory as well as service functions. The service functions to 
be  performed  by  the  federal  Government  include  defense;  external  affairs;  currency,  coinage, 
and  legal  tender;  foreign  exchange;  foreign  loans  and  foreign  aid;  nuclear  energy;  stock 
exchanges;  national  planning  and  economic  coordination;  national  highways  and  strategic 
roads;  geological  and  meteorological  surveys;  census;  railways;  exploitation  of  minerals  and 
natural  gas;  and  development  of  industries.  In  addition,  the  federal  Government  is  currently 
performing several of the functions specified in the Concurrent List.5
 The weak financial position 
of provincial governments and their overwhelming dependence on federal grants and transfers 
greatly dilutes their ability to perform several of the functions in the Concurrent List. 
 
8. 
Provincial  Government  Functions.  Functions  not  mentioned  in  either  the  Federal 
Legislative  List  or  the  Concurrent  List  are  the  responsibility  of  the  provincial  governments. 
Provinces  have  sole  responsibility  for  law  and  order,  justice,  provincial  highways,  urban 
transport,  secondary  and  university  education,  agriculture  extension  and  provision  of  inputs, 
irrigation  and  land  reclamation,  industries,  and  mineral  resources.  The  provinces  undertake 
some of the functions in the Concurrent List, including social welfare, labor exchanges, training 
establishments, and management of ancient and historical monuments and sites.

1. 
The Government of Pakistan has demonstrated strong commitment to poverty reduction, 
as  manifested  in  the  finalization  of  a  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  (PRS)  paper  in  December

responsibilities for public service delivery to local governments, with the provincial governments 
being given the responsibility of overseeing performance, providing the broad policy framework 
within  which  local  governments  are  to  operate,  and  monitoring  progress  to  attaining  social

Development  Bank  (ADB)  will  support  the  Balochistan  provincial  government  (BPG)  in

3. 
Balochistan faces unique challenges of poverty, and also unique opportunities for growth 
and  poverty  reduction.  The  main  structural  features  of  poverty  in  Balochistan  can  be 
summarized as sparse population, remoteness, and poor  physical infrastructure; intraprovincial 
geographical  and  social  diversity;  stress  on  environmental  resources;  porous  international 
borders; weak institutional presence of government; strong informal institutions of governance; 
and  highly  unequal  gender  relations.  The  low  initial  state  implies  the  need  for  sustained 
investment  for  bringing  the  population  to  a  level  on  par  with  the  rest  of  Pakistan.  At  the  same 
time, it signifies, under favorable conditions, the possibility of high rates of growth.
